item.title: The biggest Roblox creators earned an average of $1.3 million in 2025
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 9, 2026

2 Min Read

Roblox, the massive user-generated content platform operated by Roblox Corp, has revealed its top 1000 creators earned an average of $1.3 million in 2025. 

As noted in the company's fiscal report for the year ended December 31, 2025, Roblox Corp said those earnings came during a "banner year" for the platform, which attracted 144 million daily active users (DAUs) in Q4. 

Revenue also increased by 43 percent year-on-year during Q4 to $1.41 billion. Bookings rose by 63 percent to $2.22 billion over the same period.

The company explained Roblox accounted for 3.4 percent of the global gaming content market at the end of 2025, and said it remains confident of eventually capturing 10 percent of that market. 

Underscoring the popularity of its user-generated experiences, Roblox Corp revealed that Steal a Brainrot—a title purportedly crafted in four months by a group of young developers—reached an all-time record of 25 million users in September 2025. 

Related:'This is untenable:' Australian minister questions Roblox's PG rating over child grooming concerns

Roblox Corp claims AI tools can help more creators deliver hits

The company said it will be investing in AI to help its users replicate that meteoric success and noted that it has embedded AI models into its vertically integrated stack over the past four years with a view to accelerating content creation.

For instance, the company said it is building foundation models that will "support large scale, photo-realistic, multiplayer games where thousands of users (and AI powered NPCs) can come together, communicate, and compete on any device." 

"We have unique data to train these models, including 12 billion hours of human interaction data per month–not just video, but a 3D record of all avatar movement within Roblox worlds, facial expression, billions of chat messages each day–and tens of millions of users communicating through voice each day," it added. 

To date, Roblox Corp has developed and deployed over 400 models on the Roblox platform, including new tools that allow users to create intractable 3D objects and convert text to audio using 10 preset voices. 

Discussing the makeup of its player base, Roblox said it has become the "largest dedicated gaming platform for users aged 13 and under." It noted that recent mandatory age-checks have (as expected) revealed "a younger user base than self-reported data." 

35 percent of age-checked users are currently aged 13 and under, while 38 percent are aged between 13 and 17. Meanwhile, 28 percent are over 18. 

Roblox Corp said that data reveals a "larger growth opportunity in the O18 demographic relative to self-reported data," but it also serves to underline why the platform is being scrutinized (and in some instances, facing litigation) over a perceived lack of protections for its younger users. 

Related:Nintendo president says a long-term memory shortage 'may put pressure on profitability'

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.
